section.title: Problem
section.para: You want to know what list types are available in DocBook.

section.title: Solution
section.para: DocBook provides three basic lists which are used most often:

listitem.para: itemizedlist, for unordered lists (like ul in HTML)
orderedlist for numbered lists (like ol in HTML)
variablelist, for lists containing terms and their definition (like dl in HTML)

section.para: Additionally, for specific purposes, DocBook provides special lists (not explained in this topic):

listitem.para: bibliolist is a wrapper for bibliographic content. A bibliolist is usually inserted in section-like elements where a bibliography is not allowed.
calloutlist, a usually numbered list which points to a line in a listing
glosslist is a wrapper for glossary content. A glosslist is usually inserted in section-like elements where a glossary is not allowed.
segmentedlist is a list which can be used which have a one-to-one dependence with its title. A segmentedlist can be formatted in a number of ways (tabular or as a list block).
simplelist is an unordered list for single words or small phrases.

section.para: The previous lists are used to maintain semantic distinction.

section.title: Discussion
section.para: The list types orderedlist and itemizedlist are structural identical (except for its initial element) as you will see in the following subsections.
The variablelist is slightly different and contains the term element for its term.

section.title: Features of itemizedlist
section.para: An itemizedlist is a unordered list and can be written as shown in the following example:

example.title: Unordered List with Three Entries
example.programlisting: <itemizedlist> <listitem> <para>The first entry</para> </listitem> <listitem> <para>The second entry</para> </listitem> <listitem> <para>The third entry</para> </listitem> </itemizedlist>

section.para: The itemizedlist list in DocBook uses by default a disc symbol (• solid circle). If you nest an itemizedlist, it will first start the disc (• solid circle) and uses a circle (○ open circle) and finally a square (■ solid square). If you nest your list deeper, the sequence is repeated. The hierarchy looks like this:
The default bullet symbol can be overwritten with the mark attribute:
It is even possible to deviate from its default symbol in a listitem by using the overwrite attribute:
section.programlisting: <itemizedlist> <listitem> <para>The first entry</para> </listitem> <listitem overwrite="square"> <para>The second entry</para> </listitem> <listitem> <para>The third entry</para> </listitem> </itemizedlist>

section.title: Features of orderedlist
section.para: An orderedlist can be written as shown in the following example:

example.title: Numbered List with Three Entries
example.programlisting: <orderedlist> <listitem> <para>The first entry</para> </listitem> <listitem> <para>The second entry</para> </listitem> <listitem> <para>The third entry</para> </listitem> </orderedlist>

section.para: The orderedlist in DocBook numbers as arabic numbers by default. If you nest an orderedlist, it will be automatically numbered as shown in the following sequence:
section.screen: 1, 2, 3 1. level a, b, c 2. level i, ii, iii 3. level A, B, C 4. level I, II, III 5. level
section.para:
The numbering style in an orderedlist can be changed with the numberation attribute. Allowed values are
arabic loweralpha lowerroman upperalpha upperroman arabicindic .

section.title: Features of variablelist
section.para: An variablelist, despite its confusing name, holds all sort of terms and their definition. It is not limited to variables only. The following example shows how to mark a variablelist.

example.title: Definition List with Two Entries
example.programlisting: <variablelist> <varlistentry> <term>Hamburg</term> <listitem> <para>Town in the northern part of Germany</para> </listitem> </varlistentry> <varlistentry> <term>Nueremberg</term> <listitem> <para>Town in the south-eastern part of Germany</para> </listitem> </varlistentry> </variablelist>

section.para: A varlistentry can contain more than one term. How the terms are displayed depends usually on the output formats. Per default, each term is printed on a separate line.
